data.author: Boris Kr√°lik

data.text: If your cycle touring I would recommend a lightweight tent for two. Unless only doing short trips you will appreciate the space. An MSR Hubba Hubba NX is reliable and light.
data.author: Simon Dodding

data.text: What is your budget? Where and when will you be travelling? Will you be camping in mountains, or on lower ground. This will affect the kind of tent you will want, 3 season or 4 season. Are you new to camping? If you are then buying a cheaper tent makes sense. You might decide that what you need in a tent is different to what you thought you wanted when you bought your original tent. You might also decide you love it and want to spend a lot of time outdoors, then you can spend more. Or you might decide you don't like it and spending $1000 on a tent was not the best use of your money. What part of the world are you in. If you are in SE Asia it would make a lot of sense to buy a Chinese tent, as you will not be paying a lot for a tent imported from America or Europe. You may even be able to buy some tents online from sellers in your country. In some places, buying second hand is possible and it makes sense.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: new to bikepacking here. I am planning to leave 2 mouths in July / August this year, 1200km along the Atlantic coast from Roscoff to Hendaye (France). But I also plan to go through the Alps next year. About the budget, up to 400 ‚Ç¨ for good quality I would say. Maybe a bit more if it worths it

data.text: which one do you prefer ?
data.author: Juliette Mgn

data.text: Although the ‚Äòbuy the best‚Äô is often said, usually relating to hobbies, and is well meaning, I cannot agree unless you have very deep pockets, and even then. For the price of a top tent (over US$1000) I have been able to get everything I need for camping, including tent, and still have a lot of money left over. For those just starting out, I would especially NOT suggest to buy the best. Why? Because my ideas of the things I thought I needed have changed as I have gained experience. Some things I have used to death, and I can justify upgrading. Some things it turns out I have hardly used. By not spending top dollar on those things, I have limited the money spend, that can now be spent on upgrading the things I do need. Or just convert the cash to beer when on tour.
data.author: Mark Perry
